Now I can see what I'm printing without squinting. Here's a mount for a snake camera (pipe inspection USB camera) on a corner mount of my Printrbot Simple Metal. For the Printrbot corner mount, see https://www.youmagine.com/designs/printrbot-simple-corner-accessory-mount-drop-in Base unit is designed with a 6.5mm hole to fit a 1/4" bolt. You will need a M3 (3mm diameter) screw to clamp the top arm. This layout allows you to swivel on two axes. Note:

  • Camera mount has been designed for a snug fit, may require some sanding to open up the hole depending on your printer. As it is a single loop, make sure there is no free play to ensure the camera is held firmly.

  • I got this camera to work on my Macbook on OS X with FaceTime. No drivers needed.

title: tripod mount gun yoke with integrated 1/4-20 nut

description.text:
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/3PwPwnIfqOa Turn any tripod into a set of shooting sticks! Gun rest/yoke to be mounted on a tripod with 1/4-20 nut. The curvature fits my S&W X-Frame and Governor very well. Two ways to print this:
1) As is, pausing the printer to insert the nut just before the cavity is capped off. 2) On it's side, removing the bottom 1mm of the model to expose the nut cavity. My slicer settings conveniently allows this method, and it produces nicer results around the curves.

Two ways to print this:
1) As is, pausing the printer to insert the nut just before the cavity is capped off. 2) On it's side, removing the bottom 1mm of the model to expose the nut cavity. My slicer settings conveniently allows this method, and it produces nicer results around the curve surfaces, at the expense of having a truly captive nut. Mine is printed on a Printrbot Simple Metal in HIPS at 0.2mm layer height.

author: Muhalo

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/fCT4YoVxkNb

The data for this model was captured using Autodesk 123D Catch on an iPhone 5. The object is actually a 1:1 plaster model of the bronze statue which adorns the top of the US Capitol Building in Washington DC. The plaster model is in the basement Visitor Center. There is some lack of detail, particularly in the face/head region due to the fact that I couldn't get the angles there, but I'm overall pretty impressed with the outcome of the scan. There was minimal effort needed to fill some holes, trim it down, and add a base, and now you can print off your own scale replica of a piece of American History!

author: cfoy11

description.text: swag
This thing was made with Tinkercad.

We have designed Brake Disks and Shock absorbers for cars and now we wanted a challenge, over the course of one weekend we have worked on this working gear shifter with 5 gears and reverse. More info here: http://gromfrog.com We used the Concentric spinny thing from Fluffy to keep the stick in place while you can through the gate.

[Update :: 19:21 GMT 25th March 2013] We have made a modification suggested by Sirmakesalot and have combined parts 7 and 8 to make a much easier print and less assembly too. To use this new part you need to make sure it is 74mm below the bottom of the top part which is PART 6 (we have also removed the holes on this for the previous fixture). The new part is label PART 8 V2 and you need to print it similar to all other parts and just make sure you place it 74mm below PART 6 on the support rods. We also are looking in to making a simple gear box which you can control with this shifter and we have started working out the gears. We are hoping to have this finished in a couple of weeks. Print all the parts with around 10% infill but higher on the gate part which we suggest at around 30%. We also suggest you print with a raft and support or most of the parts due to overhangs. You may also have to scale parts down to fit your printer but remember to scale all the parts equally so they fit perfectly. Some sanding may be required to fit some parts together and glue will be required to hold some parts together too. You need to print the following quantities of parts:1
1X PART 1
1X PART 2
1X PART 3
1X PART 4
1X PART 5
1X PART 6
1X PART 7
1X PART 8
4X PART 9
4X PART 10
1X PART 11
1X PART 12
1X PART 13
1X PART 14
1X PART 15
1X PART 16
1X PART 17
1X PART 18 To Assemble. see the labeled diagram to assemble. you will need to place glue in most of the joints to keep them from moving.

description.text: This Thing represents some of the mechanical and electrical changes needed to implement closed-loop control on a Makerbot Replicator I - class 3D printer. More complete details documenting the method used and the results obtained are available here: https://sites.google.com/site/benweisspublic/projects/imc-closed-loop-control All the designs were done with respect to the original MakerBot Replicator I CAD files (available at this Thing); adjusting to derivative printers is straightforward. If anyone wants to modify the source SolidWorks files, I will post them too upon request. The electronics posted here are only half the story. Other parts needed are the IMC Master electronics (documented in the IMC Project) NOTE: This is a proof-of-concept implementation and NOT ready for prime time. I've documented what I've done, but a great deal of refining is needed before this will be a plug-and-play solution. The "Work in Progress" banner isn't a joke! I have implemented and tested two-axis closed-loop control using these designs. It should be possible to get a whole bot running, but the design will require a separate microcontroller for each axis. If I were doing it again, I would re-write the Marlin firmware (again!) to allow both local firing of steps to Pololus and networked closed-loop control to IMC nodes. Maybe I'll get around to it, maybe somebody else will need to do it. For other closed-loop control implementations, see this YouMagine design. It uses a simpler design philosophy and will integrate directly on top of most printer's electronics and software stack transparently. Enjoy!
More details (way too many details) are available here: https://sites.google.com/site/benweisspublic/projects/imc-closed-loop-control

I extended TBuser's OpenSCAD bitmap font module to support drawing the fonts on circles and cylinders. It centers the text along the Y axis, and fits it to the radius you specify (longer text requires larger radius).
The circles can be clockwise or counter-clockwise.
The cylinders can be on the outside or inside.

It requires the original bitmap.scad file to be in the same directory. This is an extension to the bitmap.scad, not a replacement. Include it in your OpenSCAD file (it includes the bitmap.scad), and have fun! See the 'test()' module for example usage. Keep in mind, when using these bitmap fonts, that compiling the CGAL for STL export can take a LONG time. It may look like OpenSCAD has crashed, but it probably hasn't. Let it continue working... (UPDATE 02/20/11: Made a slight adjustment to rotational spacing to allow for better handling of smaller radii. I also uploaded the 'test()' module as an STL for viewing using Thingiview (not for printing))

title: Camera Phone Stand

description.text:
Adjustable camera / smart phone stand - fits all phones up to a thickness of 10 mm including iPhone 4-5, Galaxy Nexus, Galaxy Note. The stand ball joint allows for adjustable tilt and (some) roll.
Excellent for time lapse photography, stop motion movies, web cam setups (perhaps for monitoring your 3D printer?)
This is my first model which is "not entirely useless" (quote from a PhD dissertation I witnessed). Yay!

Print in fine resolution. On my Replicator 2 the 0.1 mm gap between ball joint outer and inner parts provide quite a lot of friction, which is necessary to keep the camera fixed in all positions.
Assembly is limited to sliding the two holder parts together and twisting the stand base in place.  
To prevent the phone to slide sideways in the holder, you can add a strip of rubber or similar on the lower holder. I have used decor rubber, but bicycle hose, silicon pads, etc should work fine.
I have also placed silicon pads on the bottom of the stand to prevent it from sliding on the surface it stands on.

title: 90° bend for Ø22mm PVC Pipe Weld -Better Support

description.text:
Very similar to the previous 90° Ø22mm pipe bend, except this is built "More Vertically". I'm concerned people may confuse these for 135° bends, well, they're not. Ok, I've not seen anyone do plumbing or pipework of practical use, so I'm claiming this as the modestly named Southern Method. Using a single material home printer and Printing the pipes at 45° WITHOUT SUPPORT MATERIAL to print bed allows finished pipe profiles to be round rather than "teardrops" shapes to prevent the materials collapsing in on itself at the top. First rule of plumbing club, you don't mess with systems you don't understand.
Second rule of plumbing club, YOU DON'T MESS WITH SYSTEMS YOU DON'T UNDERSTAND(!)
Every modification will take as long as it takes.
1 system per mod,
If this is your first night at Plumbing Club, you've got to plumb. This is intended for low pressure return pipes for grey water at approximately room temperature. Do not use on Gas (Propane, LPG, Butane, Domestic Gas supplies, or any combustable media). Do not use on hot water or central heating systems (temp >40°C ; If you do not understand what ">" or "°C" means, don't use this part!). Do not use on macerated sewage. Do not use in temps close to 0°C. Do not use under floorboards or similar situations where it cannot be seen, monitored or changed easily. This design is not suitable for use in Nuclear Power Stations or Satellite Applications. Basically, use this sensibly. I've used similar in hydroponics, and it works at low pressure (102KPa / 1ATM - if you don't know what a KPa is, or what 1 ATM is, please don't use this design). I'm saying "Grey Water Systems Only" - but that's an ass covering statement, if you feel your build is safe enough to use on other systems, I'm not your keeper. I'm just an idiot. This is based on previous design
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:639743
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:650329
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:653890 Similar technique used in:
Nescafe Nesspresso Espresso Milk Nozzle
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:649314 (Kudos to similar looking for similar objects:
I like Cyber Betty's Oil Top: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:650166) I'd prefer "No Remixes" but suit yourself, I'm not your boss. If you do remix though, you absolutely must use the phrase of the day "Southern's Support-free Pipework Method". And is intended as a separate development (i.e. doesn't quite supercede the previous design). More to come. I hope you try and enjoy this. If there are previous examples of this method being used, please let me know so I can tone down my ego. THIS HAS NOT BEEN TESTED FOR WATER TIGHTNESS YET. -SOON. That's what the tear holes are for, so I can dangle above a vat of boiling Acetone. Cheers, -Andy.

A simple camera slider for time-lapse photography made from leftover parts from a 3d printer build Project.
Uses 10mm rods, 2xLM10UU and 1xLM10LUU bearings for the slider, and a M8 threaded rod and bolt for the linear motion.
The threaded rod idles in a 608 bearing, and is powered by a NEMA17 stepper motor Everything is mounted in 50mm wide C channels with 25mm hole spacing. This is work in progress. Likely updates will be strengthening of the 10mm rod mounts and the mount for the lead screw. Test videos:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mTymGbX3Rmc
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DQpCZ6nX6I8
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=w2VFO1_3QQo
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hw1-aGk7gbw Edit September 10th 2015:
Uploaded new sled with stronger holders for the transport screw, captive tab for the camera screw and offset the mounting hole so that it's more available Edit February 16th 2015:
Added a new version of the sled which locks the transport nut and has stronger walls (the old one broke) Edit February 12th 2015:
Tested the rig outdoors last night. The 1500mAh battery lasted for ~1200 exposures, and moved the carriage the full length
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9voTu-JKQ6Q Edit February 9th 2015:
Added a end stop mount for mounting standard mech endstops to the 10mm rods. New render uploaded. Edit February 5th 2015:
Added test code that moves the sled, triggers and then moves again.

comments.text: Hello. How did you fix the M8 nuts? The nuts are very loose and rotate in the place.
comments.author: reprapiran

comments.text:
Hi
Did you print the first or second version of the sled?
In the first one I hadn't added the nut locker, so they rotated freely. I fixed it on that version by screwing in thin screws between the nut and the side walls of the restraining Box. The second version fits well with the M8 nuts I have here, which should be standard.

The Steadicam Smoothee is available with mounts for several devices, but not a generic 1/4-20 tripod mount. This adapter latches into place, and can attach most anything with a regular tripod socket. You'll need to provide your own 1/4-20 screw, and possibly a washer. It's then up to you to balance your rig!

I modeled this adapter in SketchUp by measuring the base of the supplied GoPro mount for the Smoothee. Normal resolution seems to work fine, but I did use 50% infill for strength and supports for the countersunk area for the screw. If you want to get fancy, glue a thin piece of cork or rubber material cut to fit to the top surface.

This is an aid for rolling dice, in place of throwing or tossing them. When playing a game with young children it may be easier than finding the dice after erratic rolls. At least the dice will be confined to a smaller area.
For people with manipulation issues it may be easier and more consistent than the throw-release motion.

Print and clean up the exterior of the part.
Drop a pair of 16 mm dice into the top and note how they tumble to create random numbers.
This is for a pair of dice that are 16 mm cubes (roughly 5/8 inch). If you have smaller or larger dice and this does not tumble them or they wedge, simply scale it up or down appropriately.
There is the start of a hole in the bottom, which can be used to attach it to a lipped base for stability.

This is the part that attaches to the device and mates with the mount. Can be used with the Action Cam Parts (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:649261) to provide additonal options for mounting cameras. It can also be used to repair a broken mount. Please note instructions before proceeding. STEP file included for modifications. April 27, 2017 adjusted the top locking grooves to be slightly wider and deeper for a more confident locking feel. Both STL and STEP files have been updated.

What I did to recreate this part I took caliper measurements from two separate Garmin Edge devices, they were not new at the time but fit snugly in the OEM Garmin mounts. Made a few very slight adjustments to the design to account for using a 3D printer as a manufacturing technique. The model was designed in Fusion 360.

Do not print this part with any type of brittle filament, such as PLA. It should also be printed with 100% infill since it is a high stress attachment. Since the measurements are precise, please make sure to account for normal plastic shrinkage or the part will fit loose.

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58001 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=58001

I bring to you my electric clavichord design. It is a fully playable 25 key monster of an instrument. PLEASE NOTE: This project is not for the faint of heart! It contains a lot of small and large printed parts that may or may not need some "fine tuning" such as sanding, drilling holes, etc. Multiple non-printable parts need to be sourced for this instrument to be playable. Quick sound test:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HMKRCH3f2e4&feature=youtu.be
For complete printing and assembly instructions, please visit my website: http://www.diywontdie.com/clavichord.html

Print settings:
Bases- 100% infill. Best to print on side.
Keys- 10-20% infill. Print on side or upright. It is important that the keys do not warp, especially around the hole.
Key extensions- 20-50% infill. Print upright or upside down. Also very critical the extensions do not warp.
Bridge- 30% infill upright.
Tuner mount- 100% infill upside down. This part holds a lot of tension so the solid infill is important.
Key holder- 20-50% infill. Print upright.
Pickup ring- 20-50$ infill. Print upside down.
Everything at 0.2mm layer height. Supports are not needed! BOM: Printed parts:
whitekey1 X4
whitekey2 X6
whitekey3 X4
whitekey4 X1
blackkey X10
key_holder X2
*everything else is X1 Non-printed parts:
large wooden board +40" long, +9.25" wide
8/32 screws and locking nuts X28+
3/16" metal rod ~19 inches
3/16" ID washers (used as spacers between keys on rod) X24
1" slotted insert bits X25
electric guitar tuners X6
guitar or bass pickup X1

comments.text:
Awesome! The most complicated musical instrument I've seen 3D printed so far. Lots of hard work needed!
Do you use guitar strings and what are the tuning of the strings?
comments.author: licheong

comments.text: Thanks for your compliment. I used electric guitar strings (wound E and A). Piano wire might also work, but I haven't tested how much tension the printed parts can take before they fail. I experimented with a variety of tunings... if I can remember properly I tuned the lowest string to low D.
comments.author: licheong

comments.text: Take my clavichord design, replace the string bases and bridge with a 24 string retainer (<-- make this out of strong wood/aluminum) and long bridge, turn them 90 degrees, make the "key extensions" straight, replace the tangents with padded hammers, and put a sound chamber below/around. Done :D if your actually serious about making a small piano feel free to join my Musical Instruments group and we can talk about it more: http://www.thingiverse.com/groups/musical-instruments

description.text:
This is a parametric enclosure for the PanelDue controller board and touch-screen display. It supports two different 4.3 inch displays, two 5 inch displays, and one 7 inch display. The lip is optional and is intended for hanging the enclosure from the front top horizontal extrusion of a Kossel. 
Please note: PanelDue boards shipped from January 2016 onwards are version 1.1 which is 5mm narrower than the version 1.0. The OpenScad model allows you to select which size you want.
Open this object in Customizer to select the options you require. If you have a version 3.0 PanelDue controller board, select Board Version 2.0 in Customizer.

title: Earbud Holder Redux - 20% longer and more!

description.text:
We all love sneakypoo's clamshell earbud holder, but my skullcandy earbuds just didn't fit.  I wanted the cup to be about 20% longer, but scaling it in the z direction would have ovalized the pivot holes.  I ended up printing a version 20% scaled up in all directions, but it ended up being just too big.  Sadness.
So, I decided to make a version that fit my needs, and while I was at it I improved (or tried to) the design in a few ways.
1) 20% longer: now it fits my earbuds without feeling so huge in my pocket
2) Eased up the overhangs on the core piece: now they are ~45 degrees max
3) Swapped the pivot nubs for holes and vice versa.  I had issues printing the clamshell pieces because the little pivot nubs would curl up and the nozzle would knock the whole thing off the print bed when it hit them.  I swapped the design and it seems to have improved this a little, there is still a little bumping when the tops of the horizontal holes are being filled, but it's not as bad as previously.  It also adds some visual interest to a two-tone print.

Print the core with the cup facing up and with external support. Print the clamshell pieces with the holes up at the top. I did .1mm layers, 2 shells, 20% infill. Make sure to look at sneakypoo's original page for a critical tip on how to assemble the pieces without breaking them: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:36321

title: Car vent phone holder for Nokia Lumia 925 - Ver. 5

description.text:
This is Version 5 of my very simple phone holder for a Lumia 925. It holds your phone safely and can be hooked into your car vent. The holding clips may redesigned to fit your vent, but the one here should be fairly universal. Improved from ver4:
-Clips are facing up now for better hold in the vent
-Clips don't require gluing anymore. If printed well, should be able to push them into the holder with sufficient force. If it doesn't fit, sand it slightly.
-Strengthened the side features /// Please leave a comment, link your remix or upload a photo of your print. Seeing that people use and like my creations will give me motivation to create more thingis for everyone.

The files are not oriented correctly, sorry.
If someone knows a simple way of fixing this, please send me a message ;) The main part should have the large flat side facing down.
The clips are to be printed laying on their side. Once printed, push the clips into the holder with sufficient force. If unable to do so, sand them down slightly and try again.

description.text: Put your pens inside this custom PBGT Revolver! Tested it out - see instructions and photos. I'd say its a success. We use these as pen holders in our firearms training company called PointBlank Gun Training. See the website at https://pointblankguntraining.com/

Printed out at .3mm layer height on my Ultibots MendelMax 1.5. I used ABS but almost anything that is rigid should work. I used 10% infill and its plenty tough enough for pens and such. If you scaled it down by about 30% it might fit the smaller pens better, but otherwise it holds the typical bics and such just fine. You can even fit a marker in the middle hole.  
I am going to take the one I've made and rub white silicone into the text area to make it stand out better. I'll post more pictures when that has happened.

description.text: This will adapt any 1/4" hex bit to work with a 15mm wrench for use in tight areas.  In my case, I needed to remove rear deck speakers from a 2005 Ford Mustang.  The rear-most screws are only about 2" from the rear window and a ratchet or screw-driver just was not getting in there.  This adapter let me use a 15mm gear-wrench and got the job done nice and quick.  Sorry for mixing SAE and Metric, I intended the wrench size to be 1/2", but my measurement incorrect.  However 15mm works fine.

This is a puzzle box that requires a spin to unlock. The mechanism that locks the lid in place is itself locked by eight 6mm BBs, which can be printed in place, or placed during the print. A simple spin on a reasonably level surface allows the lid to be twisted 20 degrees, which allows the lid to be removed. However, closing and locking the box does not require any tricks; simply insert the lid and twist it to lock. Continuing with the idea of using airsoft BBs in the locking mechanism, I designed this puzzle box from the ground up with a few ideals in mind:
  • Easy to open if you know the trick, virtually impossible otherwise
  • Easy to close; closing the box doesn't require performing the unlocking trick
  • Aesthetically and tactually pleasing (i.e. it should look like a box but provide no clues, and it should feel solid and be fun to use)

Note: If you want to test the locking mechanism and tolerance before committing to a full print, you can print the included test models.
  • Print the top.
  • Get eight 6mm airsoft BBs ready.
    Note: You can also print a version of the bottom that includes the BBs. Just insert the lid and twist it closed like normal, and the BBs should break free. Be warned, sometimes BBs don't print well for me.
  • Start printing the short or tall version of the bottom.
  • If necessary, insert the eight BBs when their chambers are printed but before they're closed off (see the included photo).

author: MrOwnership

description.text:
I recently received a PrintrBot Plus v2.1 and have changed the z-axis to use a M8 threaded rod instead of the ACME rod that it comes with. This allows it to use the same steps-per-mm as my PrintrBot Jr v1 which has been running an M8 rod for a year. However, the spot that captures the nut and stops it from rotating, effectively creating the Z-axis, isn't small enough to stop an M8 nut. That's where these objects come in.  
They are designed to fit in place of the original ACME nut with a cutout for a M8 nut to sit. I've put these on my printrbot and have printed two very detailed objects without issue.

You'll want to print these with the spot for the nut facing up but you'll install them the other direction; with the nut facing down.   
The left/right designations are from your point of view, when you're looking at the printer's front. The right side has a slightly smaller area to put the adapter in.

comments.text: Thank you so much for this design, i ended up having to adjust the design to fit normal M8 metric nuts and i used the left side for both screws. My layer alignment is way better after this upgrade.

description.text:
Need help? No one around? No cellphone signal?
Print out your handy Bat Signal and use your phone's flashlight to call for help!! I had this idea last week and couldn't get it out of my head.
After many tries I decided to make it compatible with all mobile phones by not designing a phone-latch, instead It has a ring where you can comfortably hold the projector in font of your flash with two fingers.
It has two holes so you can attach it to a keychain for protection on the go ;)
This is an easy print, it takes about 45 minutes to print at 0.25mm. Note: This model is for personal use only and may not be used for profit

This model is designed to be printed with no supports
Once you print, hold with two fingers in front of your phone's flash light to call for help!

title: Macintosh Apple mini dock final version (Homage)

description.text:
Hi there, GOOD NEWS TO ALL, THE IPHONE 5-5S VERSION IS NOW PRINTING AND WILL SEE RESULT BEFORE I ADD IT TO THINGIVERSE FOR YOU TO DOWNLOAD) Here it is version 2! UPDATE 01:
(plus I have added two extra stl files just now to print it in parts if you have a smaller 3D printer which now have been revised as one of those parts was bringing the other, not anymore, one part on each file) UPDATE 02:
(in two parts now in this file) note i will make another version a bit smaller to fit on smaller 3D printers and perhaps another in pieces in case you have an even smaller machine***** UPDATE 03:
THIS IS DONE And upladed !!! check it out now and like it(soon I will post a baby one for the iphone 6 plus) UPDATE 04:
BUT FIRST I WILL DESIGN A KEYBOARD FOR IT THAT WILL HOUSE A THIRD PARY WIRELESS BLUETOOTH KEYBOARD I SAW ON EBAY WHICH IS CHEAP, WHITE AND LITTLE** UPDATE 05:
I have now finished designing a keyboard that will go well with it!
I received more PLA in the mail today so I will print it tonight before i go home from work.
I received my bluetooth keyboard that I bought on Ebay to use for this project, it works fine and for under $20 AUS.
I have the apple II design almost ready to print also.
Soon i will be accepting donations through PayPal to support the making of these for you all fellow apple gadget lovers. UPDATE 6:
Go and check the keyboard I made to go with it here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:673695 UPDATE 07:
  • thats it done, finito la musica, pasato la festa!
    This is no longer a work in progess
  • I am moving onto the next two projects, the imac box (which will be an iphone/s charging dock and maybe apple TV enclosure)
    and the Apple II)
  • photo adeed of new keyboard in the flesh
    • It has the apple logo and the cut out for the disk drive works without support if you print it sideways I have printed 3 of them now, it takes about 15 hours on 'fast'. http://www.wired.com/2015/01/slick-macintosh-design-inspired-first-mac-time/ So I thought it would be a neat idea to modify it to suit an ipad mini. Its finished!!! check the updated photos. update 8: (2015_10_29)
    This project has taken some time, effort and resources to design and build.
    (As you know any prototype is expensive at first, I am happy to wear the costs) please go here and help me continue creating cool stuff.
    https://www.paypal.me/justonedollar I have added rice between the scafolding within the piece before it was fully printed (rice in the gap where the base is) to add weight to it so it is nice and heavy. Thankyou Appple store in Brisbane CBD for letting me take photos at your store. Look at my other ipad mini creations. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:342809 I used ArchiCAD, I am an architect.
    I downloaded the original macintosh model as a sketch up file and import it to archicad, then I did the same for the ipad mini.
    from the article I downloaded the images and changed it to suit and kept the original proportions where I could Then I changed it a little more to be able to put in on the 3d printing bed, it just fits on my 3d touch. And I rendered it using Artlantis really quickly www.hugoriveros.com cheers Hugo
